description: The verb is from side +‎ -le (frequentative suffix), possibly a back-formation from sideling (“in a sidelong direction; askew, obliquely”, adverb), treating that word as the present participle of sidle.
The noun is derived from the verb.

verbs.description: sidle (third-person singular simple present sidles, present participle sidling, simple past and past participle sidled)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive, also figuratively) To (cause something to) move sideways. [from late 17th c.]
(transitive, intransitive, also figuratively) In the intransitive sense often followed by up: to (cause something to) advance in a coy, furtive, or unobtrusive manner.
